title: Well into the Civil War abolitionists like Frederick Douglass saw Lincoln as a pro-slavery candidate. Why was that? - Quora

response.answer_text: He never opposed slavery as immoral. The Pious Cause Narrative is that Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation was prompted by a moral concern for the black slave. Here are Lincoln’s own words regarding the reason for his Proclamation: “Things had gone from bad to worse, until I felt we had reached the end of our rope…that we had played our last card, and must change our tactics or lose the game. I now determined upon the adoption of the emancipation policy.” Lincoln in a letter to Reverdy Johnson, 7/26/1862. “I view the matter as a practical war measure, to be decided upon according to the advantages or disadvantages it may offer to the suppression of rebellion.” Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln, vol 5, p 422. “I will also concede that emancipation would help us in Europe, and convince them that we are incited by something more than ambition.” Works, vol 5, p 424. “The whole nation is interested that the best use shall be made of these territories. We want them for the homes of free white people.” ~ Abraham Lincoln, October 16, 1854. “There is a natural disgust in the minds of nearly all white people to the idea of indiscriminate amalgamation (mixing) of the white and black races. A Separation of the races is the only perfect preventative of amalgamation, but as an immediate separation is impossible, the next best thing is to keep them apart where they are not already together.” Abraham Lincoln, 1858. “Is it not rather our duty to make labor more respectable by preventing all black competition, especially in the territories... Negro equality will be abundant, as every white laborer will have occasion to regret when he is elbowed from his plow or his anvil by slave n_____rs.” Abraham Lincoln, 1860 campaign speech. “That all unoccupied territory of the United States and such as they may hereafter acquire shall be reserved for the white Caucasian race, a thing that cannot be except by the exclusion of slavery.” Abolitionist Horace Greeley interpreting the Republican Party Platform, 1856. “That barring slavery from the territories would give them an opportunity to become what New England is now, namely, a uniquely white and industrious polity.” The New York Tribune. “I make no war upon the South nor upon slavery in the South. I have no squeamish sensitiveness upon the subject of slavery, nor morbid sympathy for the slave. I plead the cause of the rights of white freemen. I would preserve for free white labor a fair country, a rich inheritance, where the sons of toil, of my own race and own color, can live without the disgrace which association with negro slavery brings upon free labor. I stand for the inviolability of free territory. It shall remain free, so far as my voice or vote can aid in the preservation of its character.” Senator David Wilmont, of Pennsylvania. 29th Congress, 2d sess., 1847, Appendix, p. 317; Lincoln was a Corporate Lawyer whose first loyalty was to the RRs and textile industry with no concern for the slave. Which is exactly why there was no plan for what to do with the emancipated slaves. When asked by Alexander Stephens (at the 2/3/65 Hampton Roads Peace Conference) “what was to become of the freedmen,” Lincoln retorted, “Let them root hog or die.” And they did die by the thousands as Dr. Jim Down’s book Sick From Freedom reveals.

While white supremacist extremists and neo Confederate authors on quora try to say Lincoln never moray opposed slavery. You can simply see that written history proves that as false. That author even includes a statement by Lincoln without quoting the end where Lincoln made it clear his personal beliefs when he said “I have here stated my purpose according to my view of official duty; and I intend no modification of my oft-expressed personal wish that all men every where could be free” That's the problem with those whitewashing history to protect and venerate slavers and white supremacy. The facts still remain. like Lincoln said “I have always hated slavery, I think as much as any Abolitionist” No hate groups will be able to erase that. Also the question is posing not based on fact. Frederick Douglass did not believe that Lincoln was an abolitionist and that he moved too slow to end slavery… but never believed he was pro slavery. He believed his close friend Lincoln could have tried more, but when Lincoln passed, stated at his funeral that Lincoln moved as quickly as he could based on what people would accept. Take a look at Douglass's monthly abolitionist newsletter in December of 1860. He called the election of Lincoln “… if not an Abolitionist, at least an anti-slavery reputation to the Presidency of the United States. “ Obviously calling him ANTI slavery is the opposite of the question claiming be called him PRO slavery.
